3.15 That is not CO2.
It is very simple ok. CO2 can not exist in the liquid form when open to the atmosphere like this, and it is very clear in the video that a white, bubbling liquid is floating on top of the water at this moment.
It is a liquid (at this moment, shortly before becoming solid) so it is definitely not CO2.

The triple point of CO2 is at 5.11 atm and -56.4 deg C. Therefore CO2 only exists as a liquid at 5.11 atm and above, that means five atmospheres of pressure (or greater) are required for CO2 to be in a liquid state, not one.

Furthermore, The density of dry ice varies, but usually ranges between about 1.4 and 1.6 grams per cubic centimeter which is heavier than water at 1.0 grams per cubic centimeter, meaning that dry ice sinks in water, it does not float. The density of solid nitrogen is 1.027 grams per cubic centimeter, and, while this is slightly more that water it is able to float in the video due to the cushion of gas it is continuously producing below it.

The stuff at the end is simply the end result of the solid piece of nitrogen that was placed into the water bath. It melted into a liquid, continued to float on the water surface before re-condensing [the same way the solid was initially produced: namely losing higher energy molecules] back into a solid and finally evaporating away.

Please understand people, even scientists make mistakes.

I just want to point out one thing though. That was DEFINITELY NOT CO2 at the end.

Instead it was from the solid nitrogen they made. My reasoning is as follows:

1. Dry ice (AKA frozen carbon dioxide) sinks. It does not float on water. If you are uncertain about this I'm sure there are probably heaps of YouTube videos showing it. [Frankly, this is all you need to know that wasn't dry ice]

2. Liquid carbon dioxide only occurs under containment, if it is open to the atmosphere it will instantly become gaseous, you would never just watch it bubble away

3. Dry ice in contact with cooled water would not sublimate into gas that fast, but when you watch the floating piece of [nitrogen] ice the gas is shooting off it

4. Carbon dioxide is heavier than air so the gas will 'pool' more than what you see in the video. instead the gas is shooting up and away more easily, it still is somewhat heavier than air but that is because the nitrogen is still so cold

5. Carbon dioxide makes up only around 400 parts per million in air. There's no way that enough carbon dioxide from the air came into contact with the water / liquid nitrogen bath to make a big lump like that. Especially when nitrogen gas is pouring outwardly from the bath and pushing away the air

What we saw was due to the solid piece of nitrogen that was clearly floating in the liquid nitrogen before it got poured into the water bath.
The warmth from the water half melted it but, as it bubbled away, it cooled more and more [just like the 'boiling resulting in cooling' explanation at the start of the video] until it became solid again [albeit now a much smaller piece]

This is the same process people and plants use to cool down (Transpiration).

ok a bit of fact checking here. it does not cool the water because only the fastest molecules escape, it cools the water because the molecules leaving are decreasing the pressure of the water and moving into a lower pressure enviroment and due to PV=NrT when pressure decreases temperature decreases. think of a swamp cooler, if only the hottest molecules evaporated that would be blowing hot humid air at you instead of cool humid air. if you evaporated all the water it would be colder than it started even though all molecules evaporated including the cooler ones
